definition: Funds provided indefinitely by the owners of a company.
Funds with repayment obligation, usually interest-bearing and time-limited.
Share with voting rights and entitlement to dividends.
Share with preferential rights, e.g. higher dividends, typically without voting rights.
Portion of profit distributed to shareholders.
Meeting of shareholders with voting and decision rights.
First-time sale of a company's shares on the stock exchange.
When the offering price of a share is lower than its first market price.
Issuance of new shares to raise equity capital.
Right of existing shareholders to purchase new shares first.
Capital approved for issuance by the board with supervisory board consent.
Period after an IPO during which insiders cannot sell shares.
Method of determining the issue price of shares based on demand.
Presentation of a company's strengths and growth strategy before an IPO.
Trading of shares without entitlement to the next dividend.
Trading of shares with entitlement to the next dividend.
Ratio of dividend to share price.
Change in dividends as a signal of future business expectations.
Strategy to stabilize dividend payments over time.
Equity component arising from share premium on issuance.
Registered share capital of a public company.
Adapting payout policy to shareholdersâ€™ tax preferences.
Trading strategy around dividend dates to exploit tax differences.
Stock performance in the years following an IPO.
Bank supporting a company during an IPO and placing shares.
